newsitem.title: USA: L.A.'s $373 mln jail opens but funding uncertain.
newsitem.headline: L.A.'s $373 mln jail opens but funding uncertain.

text.p: Los Angeles County officially opened its new $373 million downtown jail on Wednesday, but county officials said some of the funding for the facility was in jeopardy.
In order to fully fund the 4,000-bed Twin Towers Correctional Facility, the county said it planned to lease out some of its jail space to the state and federal government.
These contracts, however, have yet to be finalized, county spokeswoman Judy Hammond said.
At Wednesday's opening ceremony, Gov. Pete Wilson called on the state legislature to quickly approve the state contract with the county to ensure Twin Towers becomes fully operational.

"Public safety should be a critical concern to every member of the Assembly and state Senate and I'm confident that they'll agree with everyone here today that this facility must go forward," Wilson said.
In late January, nearly 200 inmates were moved into the facility. The jail should be fully operational by June, assuming remaining funding issues are resolved, Hammond said.
The county plans to transfer dangerous criminals currently being housed in low- and medium-security facilities into the new, high-security jail.
